questions.text: Identify the instrument used in airway management:
questions.solution:
The picture shows a first generation- classic laryngeal mask airway or supraglottic airway device. They form an important part of the airway management and difficult airway algorithm.

Reference: Dorsch - Understanding Anaesthesia Equipment, Edition 5, page no 628.

questions.text: At a constant temperature, the volume of a fixed mass of gas is inversely proportional to the absolute pressure. This law is called:
questions.solution:
Option a: Boyle's law: At a constant temperature, the volume of a fixed mass of gas is inversely proportional to the absolute pressure. V ∝ 1/P

Option b: Charles' law: At a constant pressure, the volume of a fixed mass of gas is directly proportional to the absolute temperature. V∝T

Option c: Gay-Lussac's law: At a constant volume, the absolute pressure of a fixed mass of gas is directly proportional to the absolute temperature. P∝T

Option d: Dalton's law: The pressure exerted by a fixed mass of gas in a mixture of gases is the same as the pressure it would exert alone.

Reference: Primary FRCA in a box, page 13

questions.text: The phenomenon by which the rise in the alveolar partial pressure of nitrous oxide is disproportionately rapid when it is administered in high concentrations is known as
questions.solution:
Option a: The phenomenon by which the rise in the alveolar partial pressure of nitrous oxide is disproportionately rapid when it is administered in high concentrations is known as concentration effect.

Option b: The phenomenon by which the speed of onset of inhalational anaesthetic agents is increased when they are administered with N2O as a carrier gas.

Option c: The combined action of two drugs is greater than would be expected from a purely additive effect.

Reference: Physics, Pharmacology and Physiology for Anaesthetists, Matthew E. Cross, second edition, pg 149-150.

questions.text: A 48 years old female is being induced for general anaesthesia with propofol. Which of the following effects can be minimised by giving lignocaine earlier to injecting Propofol?
questions.solution:
Propofol produces a 15-25% decrease in the blood pressure (option a) and systemic vascular resistance, without a compensatory increase in the heart rate; the cardiac output decreases by 20%.

Option c: Pain on injection occurs in up to 28% of subjects. The incidence may be reduced by the addition of lidocaine (1 ml of 1%), cooling the drug, and the use of large veins.

Option d: Bolus administration of propofol produces apnoea of variable duration (30 to ≥60 seconds) and suppression of laryngeal reflexes. Infusion of the drug produces a decrease in the tidal volume, tachypnoea, and a depressed ventilatory response to hypercarbia and hypoxia.

Reference: Drugs in Anaesthesia and Intensive Care, Edward Scarth, Susan Smith 5th edition pg 326.

questions.text: In relation to a patient having a cerebral vascular accident such as stroke, reverse cerebral steal phenomenon is mentioned with which of the following induction agents?
questions.solution:
Barbiturates cause cerebral vasoconstriction leading to a reduction in the cerebral blood flow. Because barbiturate-induced cerebral vasoconstriction occurs only in normal areas, these agents tend to redistribute blood flow from normal to ischemic areas in the brain. The cerebral vasculature in ischemic areas remains maximally dilated because of ischemic vasomotor paralysis.

Thus thiopentone sodium causes preferential perfusion of the focal ischemic areas in the brain, which is known as robinhood/ reverse cerebral steal phenomenon. But Barbiturates are not cerebroprotective in global ischemia.

Reference: Morgan and Mikhail's clinical anaesthesiology 6th edition pg 174, 591.

questions.text: A patient during induction of anaesthesia complaints of garlicky taste. Which induction agent is known to cause this effect?
questions.solution:
40% patients have a garlic or onion taste on induction of anaesthesia with thiopentone sodium.

Reference: Miller's Anaesthesia 9th edition pg 652

questions.text: Local infiltration of lignocaine and other local anaesthetic agents are less reliable for ankle block of an infected diabetic foot. This is because
questions.solution:
Since local anaesthetics are weak bases, they exist largely in the ionic form, making it difficult for them to cross the cell membrane, thus delaying their local anaesthetic action. Further they become ionised when the local tissue is infected and the local pH is acidic. Their action become unreliable.

Addition of sodium bicarbonate promotes non ionised fraction of local anaesthetic, promoting more rapid onset of its action.

Reference: stoelting's pharmacology and physiology in anaesthetic practice 5th edition pg 291

questions.text: A 20 years old burns patient with post burns contracture needs wound dressing. Which is the induction agent of choice for such a patient?
questions.solution:
Due to its intense analgesic activity, ketamine has been used extensively for burn dressing changes, debridements, and skin grafting procedures. The excellent analgesia and ability to maintain spontaneous ventilation in an airway that might otherwise be altered by burn scar contractures are important advantages of ketamine in these patients.

Reference: Stoelting's pharmacology and physiology in anaesthetic practice 5th edition pg 189

questions.text: Among the ester and amide group of local anaesthetic agents, increased tendency to develop allergic reaction is with which of the following:
questions.solution:
Esters of local anaesthetics that produce metabolites related to para aminobenzoic acid are more likely than amide local anesthetics, which are not metabolized to para aminobenzoic acid, to evoke an allergic reaction. Of the given options, only procaine is the Ester LA, all others are amides.

Reference: Stoelting's pharmacology and physiology in anaesthetic practice 5th edition pg 292

questions.text: Identify the following instrument. What is the working principle of the instrument?
questions.solution:
Beer-lambert law, which relates the attenuation of light to the properties of the material through which the light is travelling. it is used to calculate the absorbance of a solution.

the law states that the absorbance of a solution depends on:

  • The concentration of that solution, i.e. the more molecules of a light- absorbing compound there are in the sample, the more light will be absorbed.
  • The path-length of light travelling through the solution, i.e. the longer the length of the sample container, the more light will be absorbed because the light will come into contact with more molecules.

Reference: Dorsch - Understanding Anaesthesia Equipment, Edition 5, page no 1119

questions.text: Entonox is a mixture of nitrous oxide and oxygen that employs the principle of
questions.solution:
SECOND GAS EFFECT

Increasing the concentration of nitrous oxide augments not only its own uptake but also of concurrently used volatile anesthetic. This is called the second gas effect.

Concentrating Effect

Nitrous oxide is more soluble in blood than nitrogen. When a patient is given an anesthetic mixture containing N2O; some part of nitrous oxide is absorbed in the pulmonary vasculature. As a result total volume of gas in the alveolus diminishes and fractional concentration of anaesthetic mixture increases.

Poynting effect: Gaseous oxygen bubbled through liquid Nitrous oxide increased Vapor pressure of the mixture to form a gas at pressures far exceeding those capable of liquidizing nitrous oxide alone. The gases behave differently than their individual properties.

Reference: Comparative pharmacology of anaesthetist, first edition, page no: 60

questions.text: Neuromuscular blocking agents can cause dyselectrolytemia. This includes depolarising agents like succinylcholine. Succinylcholine, when administered to patients can increase serum potassium by approximately
questions.solution:
Succinylcholine is a depolarizing muscle relaxant that chemically resembles acetylcholine and attaches to the postjunctional membrane ion channel receptors. Sustained opening of ion channels produced by succinylcholine (as opposed to a transient opening with acetylcholine) is associated with leakage of potassium from the interior of cells sufficient to increase plasma concentrations of potassium by about 0.5 mEq/L in normal patients. This slight increase of potassium levels in patients with renal failure is similar to patients with normal renal function.

Reference: Miller: Basics of Anesthesia, ed 6, p 148

questions.text: Active interventions to maintain the patient's temperature include:
questions.solution:
volatile agents and spinal and epidural anesthesia, decrease the normal vasoconstrictive response to hypothermia by decreasing sympathetic tone. Hypothermia has been associated with an increased incidence of myocardial ischemia, arrhythmias, coagulopathy with increased transfusion requirements, and prolonged muscle relaxant effects. Hypothermia should be treated with a forced-air warming device, or (less satisfactorily) with warming lights or heating blankets, to raise body temperature

.

eference: Morgan, edition, page no 1293.

questions.text: Opiods act on the central nervous system to produce various effects. They produce stimulating effects on
questions.solution:
Opioids are CNS depressants. CNS depression produced by opioids characteristically has a ceiling which is subanesthetic. In simpler words they do not produce complete CNS depression.

Reference: Comparative pharmacology for Anesthetist, page no 41

questions.text: Identify the following instrument. It forms an important part of emergency resuscitation
questions.solution:
The Ambu bag comes from the acronym for 'Artificial manual breathing unit' and it is used to refer to bag valve masks;

Reference: page no 377

questions.text: Which of the following is not part of the thoracic inlet?
questions.solution: Reference: FRCA in a box, page no 225

questions.text: Which of the following is a contraindication for the use of Inhalational agents
questions.solution:
1. Malignant hyperthermia is a contraindication for the use of Inhalational agents and succinylcholine
  2. Pseudocholinesterase deficiency can cause prolongation of action of Succinylcholine leading to delayed recovery from the muscle relaxant and scoline apnea

Reference: FRCA in a box, page no 188

questions.text: Which of her following is a common side effect of the intravenous induction agents ketamine?
questions.solution: Reference: FRCA in a box, page no 181

choices.text: Main bronchi divide at equal angles

questions.text: The respiratory system of the paediatric is different from the adult in a number of ways. It includes :
questions.solution: Reference: FRCA in a box, page no 62

choices.text: Ask the surgeon to stop manipulation

questions.text: During the surgery, a 4 year old boy for squint surgery heart rate suddenly drops to 40 beats per minute . The next step in the management will be:
questions.solution:
the oculocardiac reflex is triggered by pressure on the globe and by traction on the extraocular muscles as well as on the conjunctiva or the orbital structures.

If a cardiac dysrhythmia appears, initially the surgeon should be asked to cease operative manipulation. Next, the patient's anesthetic depth and ventilatory status are evaluated. Commonly, heart rate and rhythm return to baseline within 20 seconds after institution of these measures.

Reference: Clinical Anaesthesia 8th edition (Paul G. Barash) pg 3449

questions.text: A 50 years old male who is a Jehovah's witness presents with an open femur fracture with significant blood loss and requires volume resuscitation. Which product can the Jehovah's Witness patient accept from among the following?
questions.solution:
Jehovah's Witnesses, a fellowship of more than 1 million people, object to the administration of blood for any indication.

Witnesses abstain from blood and blood products (eg, packed red blood cells, fresh frozen plasma, platelets) (option a, b and d) but not non-blood-containing solutions. They accept crystalloids, hetastarch, and dextran (option c) replacement solutions.

Autologous blood transfusion that maintains continuity with the patient's blood stream can also be used for such patients

Reference: Morgan and Mikhail's clinical anaesthesiology 6th edition pg 816.

choices.text: Breathing and mechanical ventilation lead to gastric distention
associated with vertebral anomalies, anal atresia
Positive pressure ventilation is avoided prior to intubation

questions.text: Regarding the anomaly given in the image below, choose the clinical feature at presentation:
questions.solution:
Given image is that of the most common type of tracheoesophageal fistula. It is the combination of the upper esophagus that ends in a blind pouch and a lower esophagus that connects to the trachea. These patients are at a high risk of aspiration pneumonitis and so preoperative management is directed at preventing aspiration pneumonia. This may include maintaining the patient in a head up position, using an oral-esophageal tube, and avoiding feedings.

Breathing thus results in gastric distension, whereas feeding leads to choking, coughing and cyanosis.

The coexistence of other congenital anomalies (eg, cardiac) are common. These may include the association of vertebral defects, anal atresia, tracheoesophageal fistula with esophageal atresia, and radial dysplasia, known as the VATER syndrome. The VACTERL variant also includes cardiac and limb anomalies.

Positive-pressure ventilation is avoided prior to intubation, as the resulting gastric distention may interfere with lung expansion.

Reference: Morgan and Mikhail's clinical anaesthesiology 6th edition pg 922.

questions.text: A 20-year-old G1P0 female at 40 weeks of gestation presents to labor and delivery floor with rupture of membranes and onset of labor. She appears uncomfortable and becomes extremely anxious with peripheral IV placement, and begins to hyperventilate. If allowed to continue hyperventilation, her ABG will reveal
questions.solution:
Painful uterine contractions result in maternal hyperventilation. The hyperventilation, in turn, leads to maternal respiratory alkalosis, a leftward shift of the oxyhemoglobin dissociation curve, increased maternal hemoglobin affinity for oxygen, and reduced oxygen delivery to the fetus.

Reference: Chestnut's obstetric anaesthesia 5th edition pg 458

choices.text: pregnancy reduce lower esophageal sphincter tone
stomach and pylorus are moved cephalad by the gravid uterus
Increased gastric pressure from the enlarged uterus

questions.text: A 25 years old patient with 26 weeks of gestation presents for appendicectomy. Pregnant women are at an increased risk of gastroesophageal reflux and aspiration of gastric contents during induction of general anaesthesia for all these reasons, except
questions.solution:
After midgestation, the induction of general anesthesia places pregnant women at increased risk for regurgitation, aspiration of gastric contents, and development of acid pneumonitis.

Option a: Gastric emptying is not prolonged in pregnancy

Option c: The stomach and pylorus are moved cephalad by the gravid uterus, which repositions the intraabdominal portion of the esophagus intrathoracically and decreases the competence of the lower esophageal sphincter muscle.

Option b: Higher progesterone and estrogen levels of pregnancy further reduce lower esophageal sphincter tone.

Option d: These changes in combination with the increased gastric pressure from the enlarged uterus increase the risk for acid reflux in pregnancy. Maternal gastric reflux with subsequent esophagitis (heartburn) is common in pregnant women and increases with increased gestational age.

Reference: Miller's anaesthesia 9th edition pg 2010.

questions.text: After 1 hour of tourniquet time during a right total knee arthroplasty under spinal anaesthesia, the tourniquet is released and surgical closure is started. The hemodynamic change expected is
questions.solution:
Tourniquets can produce potential problems of their own, including hemodynamic changes, pain, metabolic alterations, arterial thromboembolism, and pulmonary embolism.

  1. Cuff deflation may be accompanied by a precipitous decrease in central venous and arterial blood pressure. Heart rate usually increases and core temperature decreases (option c). Washout of accumulated metabolic wastes from the ischemic extremity increases carbon dioxide partial pressure in arterial blood (Paco2), end-tidal carbon dioxide (Etco2), and serum lactate (option b) and potassium levels. These metabolic alterations can cause an increase in minute ventilation (option d) in the spontaneously breathing patient and, rarely, arrhythmias (option a).

Reference: Morgan and Mikhail's clinical anaesthesiology 6th edition chapter 38, pg 805

questions.text: Which of the following is the single most important predictor of difficult airway?
questions.solution:
Predictors of difficult airway include

Adequate mouth opening- A normal inter incisor gap or mouth opening is more than 5 cm or 3 finger breath.

Thyromental distance or Patils test- Measured from the upper border of Thyroid cartilage to the chin, in complete neck extension. Normal is more than 6.5 cm

Sterno mental distance of SAUVA test measured from maintain stern to chin. Normal value is more than 12.5 cm. This is considered as the single most important predictor of difficult airway.

Reference: Rashid khan, edition 4, page no 24

choices.text: Tip of the uvula is obscured

questions.text: This is a method of assessing difficult airways. In stage, which of the following holds true
questions.solution:
The image shows a class of Mallampati classification of airway.

Reference: Rashid khan, edition 4, page no 22

questions.text: ASA PS classification is used to classify a patient's status before surgery, a drawback is this classification is that,
questions.solution:
The biggest drawback of the classification is that, it does not include the type of surgery involved and the associated surgical risk.


Reference: Oxford's handbook of anaesthesia, edition 4, page no 1220

questions.text: A 30 year old female patient undergoes laparoscopic removal of tubal ectopic. At the end of the surgery, the patient is extubated . Suddenly retches, vomits and aspirates. Which of the following will not form part of her management?
questions.solution:
Aspiration pneumonitis (Mendelson's syndrome). Inflammatory reaction of lung parenchyma following aspiration of gastric contents, originally described in obstetric patients. Treatment is mainly supportive, with O2 therapy, bronchodilator drugs, and removal of aspirate and secre- tions by physiotherapy and suction. Bronchoscopy may be required to remove large particulate matter.

Reference: FRCA A to Z, edition 5, page no 54

questions.text: Identify the given induction agent. The vital contents include all except:
questions.solution:
Stored as the sodium salt, a yellow powder with a faint garlic smell, with 6% anhydrous sodium carbonate added to prevent formation of (insoluble) free acid when exposed to atmospheric CO2 and presented in an atmosphere of nitrogen.

Reference: FRCA A to Z, edition 5, page no 562

questions.text: Identify the given intravenous induction agent. What is the preservative used in the preparation?
questions.solution:
Etomidate. IV anaesthetic agent, introduced in 1973. A carboxylated imidazole (five-membered ring contain- ing three carbon atoms and two nitrogen atoms) com- pound (Fig. 64), presented in 35% propylene glycol; pH is 8.1. 75% bound to plasma proteins after injection. Methoxycarbonyl-etomidate (MOC-etomidate) is a new etomidate analogue that is rapidly metabolised and does not cause adrenocortical suppression .

Reference: FRCA A to Z, edition 5, page no 218

questions.text: A patient presents with acute abdomen. They date planned for laparotomy and proceed. The patient is a known case of chronic kidney and liver disease. What neuromuscular blocking agent can be used
questions.solution: Reference: FRCA A to Z, edition 5, page no 408

questions.text: a patient is to be taken up for emergency repair of abdominal aortic aneurysm. The induction agent is choice will be
questions.solution: Reference: FRCA A to Z, edition 5, page no 408

questions.text: The muscle relaxant of shortest duration of action
questions.solution: Reference: FRCA A to Z, edition 5, page no 408

questions.text: In neuromuscular monitoring, a peripheral nerve is stimulated and the response is recorded according to different patterns. When TOF ratio is used for monitoring, which value is an indicator for extubation
questions.solution:
successive decrease in the four responses

with eventual disappearance of the fourth, third, second and first twitches at 75%, 80%, 90% and 100% blockade respectively. During recovery, the twitches reappear in the reverse order. Suggested suitable values during anaesthesia:

- TOF count of 1 for tracheal intubation.

- TOF count of 1-2 for maintenance; deeper levels may be required for complete diaphrag-

matic paralysis.

- TOF count of 3-4 before attempting reversal of blockade, especially with long-acting drugs.

- TOF ratio (at the thumb) of 0.9 for adequate maintenance of spontaneous ventilation and extubation.

Reference: FRCA A to Z, edition 5, page no 407

questions.text: The Inhalational agents are influenced by a number of patient and environmental factors. The factors that increases the Minimum Alveolar Concentration or decreasing the potency of the agent are
questions.solution:
Explanation: MAC is reduced by:

other depressant drugs (e.g. opioids, sedatives, other

inhalational agents).

CNS depletion of catecholamines, e.g. by

α-methyldopa, reserpine.

hypothermia.

hypoxaemia/hypotension.

pregnancy, possibly due to increased progesterone

levels.

extremes of age.

  • MAC is increased in: children.

hyperthermia.

hyperthyroidism.

chronic alcoholism.

It is unaffected by duration of anaesthesia, sex, acidaemia/ alkalaemia, hypercapnia or hypocapnia.

Reference: FRCA A to Z, edition 5, page no 381

questions.text: The use of nitrous oxide for a long term can result in
questions.solution:
nitrous oxide does not affect hepatic or renal function, nor uterine or skeletal muscle tone.

- interacts with methionine synthase; prolonged use may cause bone marrow depression, megalo- blastic anaemia and peripheral neuropathy. Implicated in causing fetal abnormalities and spontaneous abortion, but no direct evidence exists. Generally considered as being safe during pregnancy.

Reference: FRCA A to Z, edition 5, page no 413

questions.text: The Inhalational anaesthetic agent considered agent of choice for day care procedure and pedicures age group induction
questions.solution:
Sevoflurane increasingly being used for day-case surgery since their low blood-gas solubility promotes rapid recovery. It's sweet indoor and non pigment nature makes it agents of choice for paediatric population.

Reference: FRCA A to Z, edition 5, page no 305

questions.text: Trigger free anesthesia is a concept that avoids :
questions.solution:
: Management of known cases Malignant hyperthermia (MH).

  • pretreatment with oral dantrolene is now thought to be unnecessary.
  • sedative premedication is sometimes given to reduce 'stress', but this is controversial.
  • avoidance of known triggering agents: volatile agents and suxamethonium. N2O is considered safe. Many other drugs have been implicated at some time, but the above are the only definite triggers. TIVA is a useful technique. Local anaesthetic tech- niques may be used, but MH may still occur. All local anaesthetic agents are considered as safe as each other. new breathing system, flushed with fresh gas for 10-20 min, has been suggested as being adequate.
  • routine monitoring should include core temperature.

questions.text: The most common upper limb peripheral nerve injured during surgeries and anesthesia
questions.solution:
ulnar nerve (most common nerve injury reported): may be compressed between the humeral epicon- dyle and the operating table or arm supports,

common peroneal nerve: compressed between lithotomy pole and fibular head.

brachial plexus: usually stretched, typically by shoulder abduction and extension, with supination. Stretch is exacerbated by bilateral abduction.

Reference: FRCA A to Z, edition 5, page no 404

choices.text: Inform the surgeon to flood the field

questions.text: Air embolism is a complication seen during anesthesia and surgery. The steps of management immediately involves
questions.solution:
• Treatment of venous Air embolism:
  • to prevent further embolism:

- seal veins.

- flood the wound with fluid.

- increase venous pressure using head-down tilt, iv

fluids, jugular venous compression, PEEP. The latter and the antigravity suit have been advo- cated for prevention of air embolism in neurosur- gery in the traditional sitting position. The use of the modified sitting position with the legs placed horizontally may decrease the incidence.

  • once air has entered the circulation:

- CPR if required.

- stop N2O.

- the head-down, left lateral position is said to

increase the likelihood of air remaining in the

right atrium.

- remove air from the right atrium or ventricle via

a central line. Special wide-bore, multi-holed catheters are available for this purpose, although whether these are necessary is controversial.

- hyperbaric O2 has been used to reduce the size of the embolism and improve oxygenation.

Reference: FRCA A to Z, edition 5, page no 18

  • Treatment of venous Air embolism:
  • to prevent further embolism:

- seal veins.

- flood the wound with fluid.

- increase venous pressure using head-down tilt, iv

fluids, jugular venous compression, PEEP. The latter and the antigravity suit have been advo- cated for prevention of air embolism in neurosur- gery in the traditional sitting position. The use of the modified sitting position with the legs placed horizontally may decrease the incidence.

  • once air has entered the circulation:

- CPR if required.

- stop N2O.

- the head-down, left lateral position is said to

increase the likelihood of air remaining in the

right atrium.

- remove air from the right atrium or ventricle via

a central line. Special wide-bore, multi-holed catheters are available for this purpose, although whether these are necessary is controversial.

- hyperbaric O2 has been used to reduce the size of the embolism and improve oxygenation.

Reference: FRCA A to Z, edition 5, page no 18

questions.text: A patient develops bronchospasm at the end of extubation. Which of the following drugs is not indicated in the management?
questions.solution:
Bronchospasm. May occur during anaesthesia due to:

  • use of β-adrenergic receptor antagonists- option d
  • pulmonary oedema.
  • anaphylaxis.
  • aspiration of gastric contents.
  • pharyngeal/laryngeal/bronchial secretions or blood.
  • presence of airway adjunct or tracheal tube.
  • surgical stimulation.
  • Treatment:
  • of primary cause.
  • increased FIO2.
  • increased inspired concentration of volatile inhalational anaesthetic agent.
  • salbutamol 250-500 μg sc/im or 250 μg iv slowly.

Delivery by nebuliser or aerosol may also be used

but may be technically difficult.

  • aminophylline 3-6 mg/kg iv slowly, followed by

0.5 mg/kg/h infusion.

  • further management as for asthma.

Reference: FRCA A to Z, edition 5, page no 90

questions.text: Pulse oximetry involves non-invasive measurement of the oxygen saturation of blood. A false increase in reading can be caused by
questions.solution:
Inaccuracy may result from excessive ambient light, movement artefact, poor peripheral perfusion, elec- trical interference, venous congestion, and when SaO2 is less than 80% (as calibration data below this level are extrapolated). Response time to detecting desatu- ration varies with probe location (e.g. up to 30-60 s with a finger probe). Coloured nail polish may produce inaccuracies (tend to increase readings). Effects of other pigments:

  • carboxyhaemoglobin: most is counted as HbO, thus SpO2 is falsely high.
  • methaemoglobin and bilirubin: counted as Hb, thus SpO2 is falsely low (but may be falsely high if true saturation is very low, i.e. < 70%).
  • methylthioninium chloride (methylene blue), indo- cyanine green, etc.: may temporarily decrease SpO2 for a few minutes after iv injection.
  • fetal haemoglobin, polycythaemia: no effect.

Reference: FRCA A to Z, edition 5, page no 490

choices.text: A gamma > A delta> A alpha> B>C
A alpha> B>C >A gamma > A delta
B>C >A gamma > A delta> A alpha
C >A gamma > A delta> A alpha>B

questions.text: The correct order of susceptibility of nerve fibres to local anaesthetic agents
questions.solution:
Sensitivity of nerve fibers to inhibition by local anesthetics is influenced by axonal diameter, myelination, and other factors. In comparing nerve fibers of the same type (myelin- ated versus unmyelinated), smaller diameter associ- ates with increased sensitivity to local anesthetics. Thus, larger, faster-conducting Aα fibers are less sensitive to local anesthetics than smaller, slower- conducting Aδ fibers. Larger unmyelinated fibers are less sensitive than smaller unmyelinated fibers. On the other hand, small unmyelinated C fibers are relatively resistant to inhibition by local anesthet- ics as compared with larger myelinated fibers. In a human peripheral nerve the onset of local anesthetic inhibition generally follows this sequence: autonomic before sensory before motor.

Reference: Morgan anaesthesia, edition 6, page no 264

questions.text: While infiltration of local anaesthetic, highest chance of increased systemic concentration depending on the site of injection is at
questions.solution:
Site of injection;The rates of local anesthetic systemic absorption and rise of local anesthetic concentrations in blood are related to the vascularity of the site of injection and generally follow this rank order: intravenous (or intraarterial) > tracheal > intercostal > paracervical > epidural >

brachial plexus > sciatic > subcutaneous.

Reference: Morgan anaesthesia, edition 6, page no 267

questions.text: Which of the following local anaesthetic is used as a part of tumulescent anesthesia
questions.solution:
The 'tumescent' technique for liposuction is carried out via the subcutaneous infiltration of large volumes (5 or more liters) of solution containing highly diluted lidocaine (0.05% to 0.10%) with epinephrine (1:100,000). The taut stretching of overlying blanched skin by the large volume of solution and epinephrine-induced vasoconstriction is the origin of the term tumescent technique. The result is sufficient local anesthesia for the liposuction, virtually bloodless aspirates, and prolonged postoperative analgesia.

Reference: Stoelting's physiology and pharmacology, edition, page no 307

questions.text: The most postoperative complications of spinal anaesthesia is
questions.solution:
Neuraxial anesthesia at the lumbar and sacral levels blocks both sympathetic and parasympathetic control of bladder function. Loss of autonomic bladder control results in urinary retention until the block wears off. If no urinary catheter is placed perioperatively, it is prudent to use the regional anesthetic of shortest duration sufficient for the surgical procedure and to administer the minimal safe volume of intravenous fluid. Patients with urinary retention should be checked for bladder distention after neuraxial anesthesia.

Reference: Morgan anaesthesia, edition 6, page no 968

choices.text: Needle bevel parallel to the dural fibres
Needle bevel perpendicular to the dural fibres

questions.text: Post dural puncture headache is a common complication following neuraxial blockade. This can be reduced by
questions.solution:
The incidence of PDPH is strongly related to needle size, needle type, and patient population. The larger the needle, the greater the likelihood that PDPH will occur. Cutting-point needles are associated with a higher incidence of PDPH than pencil-point needles of the same gauge. Factors that increase the risk of PDPH include young age, female sex, and pregnancy.

Reference: Morgan anaesthesia, edition 6, page no 992

questions.text: While attending to regional anaesthesia involving peripheral nerve plexus, which block is addressed to as the 'spinal of the arm'
questions.solution:
Supraclavicular Block-

Once described as the 'spinal of the arm' due to its relatively rapid onset and reliability, a supracla- vicular block offers dense anesthesia of the brachial plexus for surgical procedures at or distal to the elbow.

Reference: Morgan anaesthesia, edition 6, page no 1008.

questions.text: A patient was administered stellate ganglion block for his right hand chronic neuropathic pain. He developed horner's syndrome on the right side. Which of the finding are features of the syndrome
questions.solution:
Cervicothoracic (Stellate) block is often used for patients with head, neck, arm, and upper chest pain. It is commonly referred to as a stellate block but usually blocks the upper thoracic as well as all cervical ganglia. Correct placement of the needle is usually followed promptly by an increase in the skin temperature of the ipsilateral arm and the onset of Horner syndrome. The latter consists of ipsilateral ptosis, meiosis, enophthalmos, nasal congestion, and anhydrosis of the neck and face.

Reference: Morgan anaesthesia, edition 6, page no 1096
